content.description: Start in left facing corner, climb double cracks on the left wall with off fingers and tight hands. Move up and left past the overlap clip the angle iron and move to anchor

this route is quite good and may have been better in the past except... There is a large flake at about 120 feet that is much looser than it looks from the ground! be careful if you chose to do this route.
content.protection: (blue tcu's thru 4 camalot) lots of ones, two, threes, and maybe a four.

content.description: Climbs a short slab to a corner up to a pedestal below a green Camelot crack (possible second pitch, significantly harder). Short pitch to entertain you while waiting for Dawn of an Error
content.location: Between Dawn of an Error and Spawn of a Terror.  Shares anchor with Spawn

content.description: The corner up the pillar immediately right of Dawn of an Error. Fingers off the ground widen to .75s before climbing some crispy face holds to change corners further right. When this crack pinches, move back left. This pitch has some cool moves, but loose rock will deter most. Perhaps it will clean up with a few ascents.

This climb is a series of 3 cracks(as I recall, it's been a long time since I was there). 1st pitch starts in a right-facing corner which fades and steps right into a thin fingers up to hands at the anchor. The 2nd pitch is a Donahue Classic Splitter! Starts out hands tapering down to thin as the crack dissapears... reach right into the next crack. Tips, to thumb-stacks, to thin hands, to hands, to fists, to 6" up to the anchor. Great 2-pitch climb....
content.location: It's been so long since I've been there... Definitely up to the right in Long Caynon on the north side of the drainage. If someone can help with a more specific location, that would be great. I remember Topher pointing out an offwidth splitter to the left that he and Craig Leuben had climbed weeks prior. I think it is near Chopper.......?????

climbs.name: Program Director
climbs.fa: K Cassidy, P Gallagher, E. Wiggans, '88

content.description:
About .9 miles into Long canyon, on the right, you will see a striking series of crack and corner systems. There is a "loop" pull-off on the left side of the road. Hike slightly up-road and towards the rock on the right to intercept a trail system on the near side of a non-distinct approach ridge. I will probably find this, but sice the beginning of the trail is not obvious, you probably won't find it right away.

A distinguishing feature to aim for is a HUGE, square, black boulder sitting a few hundred feel below the wall, tipping at the edge of a small rotton cliff band below the climbing buttress. This rock is a few hundred meters below the base of Program Director.

Program Director can be identified as a clean, solid splitter with a slight offset, starting 30' up a 'mound' in a left-facing corner, and quickly opening up to a pleasant, solid crack-climb. The line zig-zags a little and the right side is offset (sticks out) about 6-10 inches in mmost places. Just as it gets enduro, a small jog in the crack seems to appear and give you a good resting foothold.

Great line, easier with bigger hands, will probably feel closer to 10+ for small hands. I had to fist-jam some of the moves. Tape or grind!

Rap from the anchor up top with two 60M ropes! No middle anchor is there.
content.protection: A set of TCU's down to 1", with 2 cams each up to 2.5", then perhaps 4 #3's and 6 or more #3.5's. That is to lead it in a single pitch. If you like your cams closer than 10' to each other, take more 2.5-3.5" cams. two 60M ropes are required to descend (no middle anchor)

content.description: Climbs broken rock to a slabby finger crack.

The Dragon's Lair is a very challenging 150' squeeze chimney.  The start of the route is loose and chossy, but quickly turns into a classic and brutal splitter squeeze. The crux, besides endurance, is fitting through a difficult bulge. You'll know when you are at the crux when you can't get back out of it.  Double rope rappel from 2 drilled baby angles.
content.protection: 2x #4 BD cams, 1x #5 BD cams, 2x #6 BD cams, 2-3x green Bros, 1-3x blue Bros, 1-1x #9 Valley Giant is useful (and not luebben approved).
content.location: On the far right of "Dead Man's Buttress".   Obvious from the road.

content.description: The Swedin-Ringle of Long Canyon.  Narrowing splitter beginning with easy #6 camalots and decreasing all the way to tips.  There is an optional intermediate anchor at 90 ft. that forces you to clip the chains in the middle of the crux wide fingers section. Going to the second set gives you a longer, more varied experience with a good stance to clip the anchors from.
content.protection: Triple set of cams tips to #2 camalot with one #3 and an optional #6.  if you're stopping at the first  anchors you don't need anything smaller than #.5 Camalot.
content.location: The first classic-looking splitter encountered up canyon from the North Spur (The side canyon containing the Shipyard crag.) on the sunny side of Long Canyon at the Deadman's Buttress.

climbs.name: Chopper
climbs.fa: Katy Cassidy, Carol Petrelli, Earl Wiggins  1988

content.description:
Chopper is the left facing corner that the trail up to the cliff for Chalk is Cheap takes you to.  It is 50 feet left of Chalk is Cheap and maybe two corner systems over.

Quite sandy, could be done in two pitches, but better as one.  Rap with two ropes.
content.protection: Triple set of cams to fists, extra wide hands, a #4 camalot.

content.description:
This is one of the furthest left, a few left of the more obvious Program Director.

Pitch 1 )  60- 70 feet. Mostly thin hands, fingers and some odd variety to keep it interesting.

Pitch 2 ) we did not climb it, with the sketchy rock at the traverse from the anchor with poor pro it was not too inviting, looked like more big gear then book suggested.
content.protection: .5 - #4, mostly #1, #2. 2nd pitch looks like maybe 2) #4, a #5 too and more in the #3 size.
content.location: a couple left of Program Director, right of Shit Eatin' Grin.

content.description: Very delicate and then burly, the two pitches of this Copeland masterpiece represent opposing ends of the Wingate spectrum of excellence.  The upper section of the slab and stemming corner requires balance based more on faith than feasibility and then the mood changes to overhanging fists reminiscent of the crux of the Yosemite classic Freestone.  Above lies an ample dose of great thin hands and the anchor.
content.protection: Bring a single set of cams to red camalot and ten quickdraws for the mostly bolted fist pitch and many fist and thin hand sized pieces (with a couple cams of the sizes in between) for the big steep corner above.
content.location: At the Deadman's Buttress on the north side of Long Canyon, a five minute walk to the right of Program Director.  Chalk is Cheap is the only bolted  route at the crag and the overhanging left-facing corner of the second pitch is very obvious.  Descend via good bolted anchors.
